searchDocs.title: Types of Joints​
searchDocs.content: There are several types of joints including:

searchDocs.title: Fixed​
searchDocs.content: A fixed joint is a joint that does not move. It is used to connect two links that are rigidly attached to each other.

searchDocs.title: Revolute​
searchDocs.content: A revolute joint is a joint that allows rotation around a single axis. It is similar to a hinge joint.

searchDocs.title: Prismatic​
searchDocs.content: A prismatic joint is a joint that allows translation along a single axis.

searchDocs.title: Continuous​
searchDocs.content: A continuous joint is a joint that can rotate indefinitely.

searchDocs.title: Planar​
searchDocs.content: A planar joint is a joint that allows motion in a plane.

searchDocs.title: Floating​
searchDocs.content: A floating joint is a joint that allows motion in 6 degrees of freedom.  Listed below are optional attributes that can be added to the joint element:

searchDocs.title: Links
searchDocs.content: Links Links are the elements that define the shape and size of the robot. They are the building blocks of the robot and are connected by joints.

searchDocs.title: What is the URDF?
searchDocs.content: What is the URDF? This module covers what is the URDF (Uniform Robotics Description Format) and why it is important in the context of robotic development and ROS2. URDF (Unified Robot Description Format) is a file format for specifying the geometry and organization of robots in ROS URDF's are made up of 2 basic elements Links and Joints. Links are the elements that define the shape and size of the robot. They are the building blocks of the robot and are connected by joints. Joints are the elements that connect two links in a robot. They define the relative motion between the links. Citations: D. Tola and P. Corke, "Understanding URDF: A Dataset and Analysis," in IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters, vol. 9, no. 5, pp. 4479-4486, May 2024, doi: 10.1109/LRA.2024.3381482

searchDocs.title: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
Introduction​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: The URDF Creator is a powerful tool tailored for ROS2 users, facilitating the creation of robot models within the ROS ecosystem. The URDF is a Unified Robot Description Format that defines the geometry, kinematics, joint connections, sensor specifications, aswell as transformations between frames provided by robot state publisher.

searchDocs.title: Understanding URDF​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: Before diving into the tool itself, let's briefly discuss the Uniform Robotics Description Format (URDF). URDF serves as a standardized XML-based format for describing robots in ROS. It encompasses various elements such as links, joints, sensors, and visuals, all crucial for accurately representing a robot's physical structure and kinematics.

searchDocs.title: Links and Joints​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: Links represent physical components of the robot, such as wheels, arms, or sensors. Joints define the connections between these links, enabling movement and articulation.

searchDocs.title: tf2 Library and Frames of Reference​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: In ROS2, the tf2 library manages coordinate frame transformations, crucial for understanding the spatial relationships between different components of the robot. Each link and joint in the URDF corresponds to a frame of reference, allowing seamless integration with ROS2's tf2 framework.

searchDocs.title: Exporting a URDF​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: Once you've designed your robot model using the URDF Creator, the next step is to export it for integration into the ROS2 ecosystem. The exported URDF file serves as the blueprint for your robot's virtual representation within ROS, enabling simulation, visualization, and control.

searchDocs.title: Exporting Process​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Quick Start - Building a ROS2 Robot
searchDocs.content: We'll walk you through the simple process of exporting your URDF file from the URDF Creator, ensuring compatibility and seamless integration with other ROS2 tools and packages.
